entry.title: Handle Facebook session expiry with Facebooker
entry.content:
Facebooker is the most commonly used ruby interface to the Facebook API. It is considered stable and generally is being kept up to date with the frequent-and-annoying Facebook API changes.

Facebook has some strict rules you have to consider when using their API and FacebookConnect integration, one hidden rule for example, says something like that:

“If you use Facebook Connect on your site, the cookie that we are going to use, is the same cookie we keep for our main site,
Facebook.com”

Meaning basically that if a user is connected to your application (via Connect or through FBML, doesn’t really matter if it’s FBML) and he or she logs out of the main facebook site, they will also log out from the Facebook session on your application. Basically saying, that the user’s facebook session in your application, can be reseted without an explicit action from the user on your site. epic win facebook.

In order to handle that kind of situation you’ll have to rescue the Facebooker::Session::SessionExpired and use the failsafe Rails method named rescue_from:

This will clear up all the Facebook remnants in your user’s session and will force him to reload.

Note that if the user granted you with the “offline access” permission and you saved the credentials, you will be able to restore the session without notifying the user.

entry.title: Bag O' Links - 3/11/2009
entry.content:
• First look at Rails 3.0.pre – Dr Nic’s first attempt on the upcoming Rails 3 pre release.
  • Rails practices slide – this one has actually more than 2 good ideas inside.
  • drier gem configs – @hakunin is doing it again, now a better more readable way to specify your config.gem.
  • Easily create a javascript framework – obviously a lie, thu worth the read.
  • Javascript minifying tools – a quick set of tools for reference.
  • Know when to fold’em – one way to handle too many open source projects.
  • git-wtf – a script to display the state of your repository in a readable and easy-to-scan format.
  • using the new gem bundler – this will be an integrated part into Rails 3, better start now.
  • method aliasing in Ruby – and why chaining is potentially evil.
  • web design with pixelmator – meh, but i like pixel mator.
  • simple_importer tutorial – how to import csv into your Rails app.
  • w3c gets a new home – navigation totally changed, not sure if it’s right or not.
  • Using MongoMapper – a brief tutorial on how to use this MongoDB OM gem.

Treasures

  • spork – A DRb server for testing frameworks (RSpec / Cucumber currently) that forks before each run to ensure a clean testing state.
  • resque – A simple Redis-based queue.
  • autoMySQLBackup – A script to take daily, weekly and monthly backups of your MySQL databases using mysqldump.
  • trap_door – lure those spam bots into oblivion.
  • fluid_grid_system – A lightwieght XHTML/CSS framework that follows both the typographic grid, and also baseline grid
  • faketwitter – a fakeweb extension to fake twitter responses.

entry.title: Bag O' Links - 30/10/2009
entry.content:
• sammy – super awesome javascript MVC framework, based on jQuery and feels like sinatra. looking good.
  • underscore.js – a functional javascript library, based on jQuery too with some cool extends to javascript objects. pay attention to the discussion on Reddit
  • intro to Ruby – by Brian Hogan – awesome slides by @bphogan, bare through the “Programming is fun” slide and enjoy :)
  • Explorer Exposed – common bugs and fixes for IE hell.
  • Git Magic – another new Git book for all of you infidels/
  • Atlas – an Xcode style Interface builder for web applications, coming soon.
  • cache_counter gotachs – a warning from Ryan Bigg.
  • 300 rails links – i don’t know how updated it is, use at your own risk.
  • pig – an Hadoop high level abstraction of parallel processing, super neat.
  • ThinkingSphinx RSpec matchers – test Thinking Spinx’s setup block.
  • imporving your code with Metric_fu – a good article from Devver.
  • Building an iPhone Application – a good post by DeveloperZen, covering the creation of a new application and the tools they used.
  • Off github – a solution by @hakunin to help in migrating your gems from github to gemcutter.

Treasures

  • nanite – scalable message queueing.
  • yUMLmeRails – Use yUML to generate Rails diagrams using RailRoad and Shoes
  • quick_serve – a super-simple way of serving static files for development. It was made mainly for javascript and css development, but might have other uses.

entry.title: Using BlackBird javascript console in Rails
entry.content:
BlackBird offers a dead-simple way to log messages in JavaScript and an attractive console to view and filter them. Although most of us are already familiar with the FireBug console, BlackBird supplies us with an easy, simple and Cross Browser live console that is available upfront anytime you’d like.

BlackBird_rails is a plugin i created to simplify the integration of BlackBird into your rails applications, simply install it by invoking:



> script/plugin install git://github.com/eladmeidar/blackbird_rails.git

and the required javascripts, stylesheets and images will be copied into your public/ folder. Next thing you’ll probably want to do is adding the include_black_bird snippet into your <head> block:





  

    <%= include_black_bird %>

    …

Which will add the blackbird javascript and CSS tags. It’s also important to point out, that the helper will only generate these tags when running the development environment, so you are hassle free regarding that matter.
you’ll still be required to remove all log.something calls in your javascript source, otherwise IE is going to be mad at you.

From this point on, you can use BlackBird exactly as the home page explains.

Quick Tip

Drag this bookmartlets into your favorites toolbar and you’ll be able to:

  • clear
  • move
  • resize
  • and toggle

your BlackBird window anytime you’d like.

entry.title: Bag O' Links - 27/10/2009
entry.content:
• Juice – Juice is a javascript server-side web framework, i am not a fan of server side javascript, but i keep the options open.
  • Dr Nic’s install-theme – import any HTML template to your rails projects, a brief tutorial.
  • Foreui – a mockup design application, looks a bit more packed than Balsamiq Mockups.
  • Good Ruby Times – some advices and practice ideas for a bunch of code reviews, good stuff to read and learn.
  • Amazon’s RDS – Amazon recently released their new MySQL Relational Database Service, this is a good post on the aspects, usage and observations of using RDS.
  • 1K grid – a small neat CSS grid layout generator.
  • BigRecord – Column-oriented Data Mapping for Ruby on Rails, not that i have any idea what that is.
  • RubyGems.org – GemCutter becomes the #1 source for Ruby gems.
  • and on that note move your gems to gemcutter – a gem from hakunin that helps in the process.
  • BluePrint CSS tutorials – a brief tutorial.
  • eCSStender – subdue browsers to your CSS.
  • Flash like jQuery – games, effects and other fun-ness.
  • CodeRack – a Rack Middleware competition, those of you who care about Rack existence, will find some cool stuff in the projects list.
  • jsbin – live javascript debugging.
  • NoSQL misconceptions – some explaining done by the guys at viget.
  • Ruby Metaprogramming first steps – How, when, where and why.
  • Google’s attention to RDF and Microformats – a small change in attitude.
  • Better jQuery and JS coding – nice tips. i didn’t know about $(selector).data.

Treasures

  • Ancestry – Organise ActiveRecord model into a tree structure, extra methods included.
  • ActiveHash – A readonly ActiveRecord-esque base class that lets you use a hash, a Yaml file or a custom file as the datasource.
  • ROMA – key value store for Ruby (among others).
  • Irwi – Wiki plugin for ruby on rails.
  • jquery.concrete – Concrete UI programming library for jQuery
  • geo_mere_laal – integrate browser locationing in rails.
  • interfacelift – a collection of templates for rails applications.
